page.title: 04Weston Wharf
page.content: In 1797 the Ellesmere Canal Company built a branch of the Ellesmere Canal as part of an attempt to connect Liverpool and Bristol by an inland waterway via the Dee, the Mersey and the Severn. Attempts to reach the Severn at Shrewsbury ended at Weston Lullingfield through lack of money. Weston Wharf, with its limekilns, stables, clerk's house, weighing machine and public house became a very busy centre of economic activity. Lime, slate, coal and bricks were brought for sale in the area. Local timber, cheese and farm produce were shipped out. The chains for the Menai Bridge were brought by road from the Midlands and shipped from the Wharf. Trade declined with the building of the railway in the 1840's.
